title: For Sale:  SCARCE WINCHESTER M1894 LIMITED EDITION I FROM 1978
postcontent: FABULOUS Winchester Model 1894 Carbine Limited Edition I, manufactured in 1977 - 78 as a limited edition of 1,500. Winchester combined richly colored and highly figured American walnut with deeply blued and gold plated metals to produce an heirloom collectible centered on the legendary Model 1894 lever action carbine chambered in the .30-30 caliber. The receiver features deep relief John Ulrich pattern engraving with game scenes on both sides of the receiver. The accompanying Winchester booklet states that the engraving is “a classic reproduction of one of the finest styles developed under John Ulrich at the start of the 20th century. American-style scroll-work and animal scenes became a recognition point of supreme quality.” The receiver, barrel band and lever are gold plated with a soft luster matte finish. The wonderful stocks are XXX fancy walnut with a fine, multi-point checkered walnut forearm and straight grip stock. The butt stock is graced with a smoothly curved crescent, steel buttplate. The 20 inch blued, round barrel is mounted with a ramped, adjustable buckhorn rear sight and a blade front sight. Two blued barrel bands hold the barrel to the forearm and to the cartridge tube magazine. The barrel is inscribed on the right rear side with “LIMITED EDITION BY WINCHESTER” in cursive script. This beautiful rifle comes with a fitted presentation case that appears to be walnut topped, with mahogany sides and bottom. The case interior is lined in wine colored fabric. Includes a covered compartment for a box of cartridges (not included) or accessories. Leather "Winchester" label on the inside of the top. The case has three brass latches with the center one incorporating a key lock. The bottom of the case is covered in green felt. Case dimensions are: length at 42 ½ inches; width at 10 3/8 inches; height at 3 1/8 inches. Papers include: Winchester Limited Edition booklet, serialized in hand to the rifle; a letter from Phil H. TBD, President of Olin Winchester Group indicating that this Winchester was manufactured on February 22, 1978; 13 cent address envelope to be used to order a custom brass name plate for the case; Winchester “Sporting Arms Purchase Card”. Complete with original box numbered to the rifle and sleeve, and case shipping box. Rifle Weight is approximately 6 pounds 5 ounces. LOP is approximately 13 ¼ inches. New in case, with only the slightest handling/storage marks overall. The case is excellent with a few scattered handling marks. This is one of the finest examples of this Limited Edition that we have offered. Payment procedure is through Money order, Western union. No Meeting cash

postcontent: This is an unissued/new USGI military rifle Model 16 or AR15 OR M4 portable shipping/protection case. Designed to hold 12 rifles this case is made protect rifles from damage, weather, moisture and high altitudes. The hard plastic exterior has 14 metal lock down latches. title: For Sale:  Trijicon REFLEX RX30 with ARMS mount
postcontent:
For sale: One genuine trijicon 6.5 MOA amber dot RX30-23 with ARMS quick detach mount.  This optic was rarely used and it is in like-new condition (no damage whatsoever) optic was manufactured in 2012.  This is one of the best optics for a KSG.  Comes with the optic/mount, scope coat cover, and manual.  Sacrifice for 450 shipped.  

Awesome reflex

My experience with the RX30 has been a positive one.  It quickly became my favorite reflex sight to date (I have used multiple meprolight and trijicon reflex sights in the past as well as eotechs, etc)  The larger 42mm objective and 6.5MOA dot provides quick target acquisition and wide field of view especially with both eyes open applications (perfect for a rifle or shotgun, but in my opinion it really shines on a shotgun).  I had this on my kel tec KSG.  It was an awesome set up, with the ARMS mount I was able to place it and move it easily until I found the perfect spot.  

A quick note on dual illumination:  If for some reason you are worried about bright light flooding out the amber dot I have a suggestion.  I never needed it but if you are in an environment that you think it may wash out you can tape a cyalume mini chem light to the side of the optic.  That will ensure an exceptionally bright dot for four hours.  If this truly was a problem, trijicon would not sell these.  This is merely a suggestion for those that may be weary about washout.  

If you are in need of reflex sight, this is the one.  My new 870 is for breaching so I no longer need this.  Please ask if you have any questions.

title: For Sale:  Browe 4x32 BSO blackout reticle
postcontent:
For sale: one like new condition Browe BSO (Browe Sport Optic) 4x32 power with the AAC Blackout reticle.  This optic comes with an ARMS quick release mount, bikini covers, original box and accessories.  650.00 shipped to you.

My review

The BSO is in my opinion, one of the better optics on the market.  Built to endure the similar hardships an AR15 may see, I believe a better name would be Browe Survival Optic versus Sport Optic.  I will not expound on the quality as it is as well built as any ACOG.  I enjoyed this optic due to a combination of need, design, and price.  

Need - I wanted a short to mid range optic with 300 blackout reticle.  I want to high-quality glass, durability, ease-of-use, and an illuminated reticle.  

Design - the BSO met and or exceeded this criteria.  I especially like the Rechargeable illumination technology feature.  With this feature the optic has no buttons or batteries, you simply charge the reticle with a flashlight.  In low light or darkness the reticle is not overly bright, rather it is exceptionally clear.  The reticle itself, is in my opinion, is an exceptional reticle for the 300 blackout.  It is a combination of two bullet drop compensators, one for sub sonic (400m) one for supersonic (900m).  Both sides have man-size (shoulder width) milling hash marks out to their perspective yardages.  I really like this reticle.  However I have only tested it with subsonic and supersonic out to 300 yards.  Again speaking of needs, for my purposes 300-400m is the top end for a mid range optic.  However from 1 to 300 yards the reticle was very precise with both super and subsonic ammunition (barnes 110/remington 220).  Based off the leupold reticle, the browe reticle - although similar, is a bit different.  BROWE INC says:
August 30, 2012 at 16:34
The concept of the AAC .300 blackout reticle was benched marked off the Leupold reticle. The horseshoe and dot reticle is not unique and is being offered by many manufactures. Referencing stadia lines with for multiple calibers has also not unique and has been done for years. The reticles are similar, but different. He’s is a listing of the Browe reticle specs:

1.	The 4×32 BCO/BSO AAC .300 Blackout reticle is based in meters vs. yards 
2.	The width of the reference stadia lines are 19” vs. 18”
3.	The BCO top of the stadia tree comes to a point for an accurate 200m pin point shot placement and is illuminated vs. squared off and not illuminated
4.	Our outer ring is 7moa vs. 7.5moa
5.	Our horizontal reference is a MIL reference vs. referencing target speed
6.	Our 1moa dot is zeroed at 100m supersonic and 25m Subsonic vs. 100m / 50m
7.	The BCO is designed for different bullets, compare the 100m subsonic crosshairs
8.	Stadia lines are .5 moa vs. unknown
9.	Subsonic / Supersonic is spelled out vs. using images

Having used both reticles,  I will say the Browe offerings do not trump the leupold design, however it is indeed a solid, useful design. 

Price - through SWFA I purchased this optic for $800.  This price included the ARMS mount (which was surprisingly well built and easy to use).  I was skeptical paying this much for manufacturer and optic I have never used.  After receiving it and using it I would say the Browe BSO does fall into that price category.  Along with the exceptional quality and durability it is always a plus to be made in the USA.  

Conclusion - I believe the only reoccurring complaint about this optic (and other 4 power optics) is the eye relief.  Yes 1.5 inches it's very close (nose to charging handle - which is a known reference point for fast shooting). This is no rifle scope.  It is a short to midrange optic, and it covers and performance in these ranges very well.  My point is when you purchase an optic it usually is mission or need specific.  

I believe this is an exceptional optic, especially for the AR - 300 blackout platform.  It gives the Shooter up close to midrange capabilities with both super and subsonic ammunition.  Also have nighttime illumination without tritium or batteries.  Lastly, speaking of needs again, I no longer need this optic.  I wish to move on and test the leupold mark 4.  As I am looking forward to testing it, I'm looking forward to selling this to someone with similar needs.  

Thank you for your time and if you have any questions regarding the optic please ask.

title: For Sale:  Albanian SKS 1970
postcontent:
Hard to find Albanian SKS made in 1970. Non matching numbers. It is in good condition, the finish is pretty well intact, it functions great.

The differences between the Albanian SKS and those from other countries are:
1) The extended length stock and the extended 3 vent upper handguard that extend all the way to the gas block.
2) The trapdoor butt plate has 2 doors rather than the normal one.
3) The Albanians use an AK style charging handle rather than the round style used by all other countries.
4) The Albanian rear sling swivel is located on the left side of the butt stock as compared to the bottom of the butt stock on other models.
5) The 10 round fixed magazine on the Albanian has a slightly different bottom profile than those on other SKS's.

There were an estimated 16,950 produced. For unknown reasons the Albanians destroyed or gave away nearly two thirds of them and it is believed that only 5,700 are left in the world today.

title: For Sale:  IOR Valdada Pitbull 1:4 QR-TS compact scope
postcontent:
For sale: one like new IOR valdada pitbull scope.  The scope comes with the IOR cantilever mount, instructions, and original box.  Everything is like new.  This is the newest, most recent generation of the pitbull with the side illumination dial.  

If you buy this for 1000.00 you will get:
- IOR Pitbull 1:4 (from the original owner purchased from factory in Colorado)
- IOR pitbull scope mount (non-quick release with steel bolts)
- All original content (box, paperwork, etc)
- Insured and shipped to you with tracking 

Would consider trade from leupold cq/t with a cmr2 reticle

About the scope

The pitbull is an excellent choice if your intention is to have an optic for CQB to mid range applications.  In my opinion it really shines on a M4/AR15 shooting 55gr or 62gr ammo.  I have used it for both of these applications and the results were extremely favorable.  It's compact size coupled with the 35mm tube make for an easy to use CQB package.  At 1X power, targets are easily acquired with the flaming red dot through the remarkably clear glass.  At 4X targets are easily identified at farther ranges and the reticle BDC is spot on with XM193 and or XM855.

I do recommend the newest generation of this scope.  If you call IOR valdada they will tell you all other versions are obsolete as compared to newest gen.   This is especially true with the illumination.  I believe this is the first generation with a true daytime illuminator.  

 The only vice I could find with this scope is the weight.  It is heavier than other scope in its class.  However I believe the options you get with the pitbull out weight the weight issue.  If your quest is to possess the lightest set up, look elsewhere.  If you want a uniquely designed scope for two-eye applications with the addition of having 4X for your mid range needs this is it.  

I've enjoyed the time I've spent with this optic.  I'm now after a 1-3, 1-6,or 1-8 power so I no longer need it.  If you are interested or have any questions please ask.

title: For Sale:  ar15/10 muzzle brakes 1/2x28, 5/8x24 m18x1
postcontent: I make these out of stainless, they are cut on a 4th axis cnc and turned down a lathe. All brakes are cut to a .920 outside diameter and threaded to either your 1/2x28 or 5/8x24 thread pattern. they can also be turned down where they touch the barrel to match your exact diameter. So the Outside Diameter will be .920 but where it mounts can be .750 or whatever you want. This give the appearance of a brake that's build for your barrel and not an off the shelf brake. It is recommended that you use a crush washer (these brakes are cut with a 82 degree angle where it mounts) or a shim kit. I personally recommend the shim kit.

postcontent:
MN Residents can pick up.  Permit to purchase(free from local Sheriff) or CCW required.
Non Residents: Will ship to FFL of your choice. Please inquire about payment method and shipping.

DPMS RFLR260 260 PANTHER LR-260 260R 24" SS BULL LRA3 19RD REDACTED97 

24" length , 416 stainless steel bull barrel, fluted, 6 grooves right hand 1x9 twist, button rifled

Review:
he .260 Remington cartridge provides the shooter with mild recoil and relatively long barrel life. The shorter barrel in the .260 DPMS hunting version does sacrifice velocity, but it is not meant as a long-range rifle. For example, my sniper rifle with a 25" barrel pushes 139 to 142 grain bullets at 2870 fps. The .260 LR AR with a 24" barrel reduces that to about 2750. The hunter version with an 18" barrel slows the bullet to about 2550. For comparative purposes, all were shot and chronographed using the same load of 45.3 grains of H4831sc (a mild load) and 139 grain Lapua Scenar bullets. If one believes that only 1000 ft-lbs of energy is required for whitetail deer, the 260 Remington in the short barreled AR is good to 575 yards. And in the right hands, it performs admirably at long range. A friend, Andrew Smith, took the rifle to one of my 11" wide x 22" tall steel LaRue targets at 900 yards on a recent deer hunt.

title: For Sale:  S&W 1 & 1/2 2nd issue, factory nickel, ammo included!
postcontent:
S&W 1 & 1/2 2nd issue FS. Finish is poor with scuffs, minor pitting along frame, heavier pitting on cylinder. Sideplate is missing large portion of nickel plating. Bore is good, although there is some minor pitting just forward of forcing cone. Rifling still sharp & intact. Grip panels fair, although do show age. Action is tight & is shootable. 

Approximate mfg. year of 1863. Period correct for civil war reenactors portraying Union officers, or for Cowboy Action Shooters who want something a little more authentic. 


This sale of this antique includes:

1. Full box of brass cased Navy Arms .32 Rimfire (long), along with five loose rounds of the same. Box and ammunition are in excellent condition. 

2. Partial box of antique, copper cased UMC .32 Rimfire Long ammunition. 13 original pieces remain, contents fair, although projectiles have oxidized. Box in good condition, edges worn. 

3. Three rounds of antique, copper cased Winchester headstamped .32 Rimfire Long ammunition. Excellent condition. No box. 

4. Three rounds of antique, copper cased UMC headstamped .32 Rimfire Short ammunition. Projectiles corroded/oxidized, casings in good condition. No box. 

5. Nearly full box of antique US Co (Lowell Mass.) .32 Rimfire short blanks. 49pcs. Box in great, but not excellent condition due to wear on edges. Contents in good condition. Retains 100% of all markings. Copper casings. 

6. Partial box of antique Winchester .32 Rimfire Short blanks. 35pcs. 7 or so have been damaged by the previous owner attempting to ignite them in a centerfire firearm, although they are still intact, and usable. Box is in good-fair condition, as one flap has been torn. Retains 100% of all markings. Copper casings. 

7. 44pcs. of antique, copper cased UMC .32 Rimfire Short blanks. Good condition, no box. 



This is a great, great piece of history to have. These pistols were the choice of union officers during the civil war. 

Any collection would do well to include an antique S&W of this vintage, and the ammunition to accompany it. The empty boxes alone are collectable. Antique ammunition & the blanks of this vintage alone are astronomically priced. The Navy Arms ammunition that comes with this alone is worth $2/round and is very hard to find. 

Great investment, I just need the cash. Times are hard, and unfortunately this one has to go, and soon. $600 takes it all away (there's $400 worth of collectible ammunition & boxes here). 

Priced to sell. Anyone that is serious about making an investment or adding an antique S&W to their collection, this is for you. 

Entirely open to fair offers. Willing to drive provided you have cash in hand. As said before, times are hard & I need cash. 


No shipping.
